descriptions.description: High-quality software with more features enhances the project's perceived value and public standing.
A larger user base provides more testimonials and visibility, which bolsters the project's reputation.
More core developers increase the total workload for reviews, potentially slowing down the process.
Longer review delays give maintainers more time to provide comprehensive and detailed feedback.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review generates a greater volume of feedback activity.
A rich base of implicit knowledge provides more material for experienced members to share through mentorship.
More core developers increase the available mentors, enabling more frequent and effective knowledge transfer.
Constructive feedback encourages newcomers, increasing their retention and transition into active contributors.
Positive and helpful feedback motivates experienced contributors to remain engaged and continue contributing.
Effective feedback helps skilled contributors progress and be promoted into core developer roles.
New contributors ask questions and seek clarifications, which generates more feedback interactions.
Experienced contributors provide detailed reviews and answers, increasing the volume of feedback.
Ongoing feedback cycles keep pull requests active and in the review queue longer.
Well-documented explicit knowledge makes it easier to create guides and onboard new contributors.
Feedback from reviews and discussions is often documented, adding to the searchable knowledge base.
Resolved issues and their solutions are archived, expanding the project's searchable knowledge base.
A comprehensive knowledge base serves as a primary source for the project's documented explicit knowledge.
Community discussions generate questions, answers, and decisions that are added to the knowledge base.
A strong project reputation attracts more users, growing the user base.
More open issues generate more user reports, questions, and community feedback.
User feedback often reveals new problems or feature requests, leading to more open issues.
A healthy, collaborative community is a positive signal that enhances the project's reputation.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, making it easier for new contributors to join.
A clear and fair governance strategy makes the project more attractive for potential contributors to join.
An effective governance strategy encourages participation, increasing the rate at which new contributors join.
A project's high reputation attracts more developers, increasing the contributor joining rate.
More maintainer time dedicated to issues accelerates the rate at which they are resolved.
Faster issue resolution directly increases the stock of closed issues.
Newly created issues flow into and increase the stock of open issues.
Resolving issues removes them from the open issue backlog, decreasing its size.
A larger codebase has more complexity and surface area, leading to a higher rate of issue creation.
Positive project activities and outcomes accumulate over time, building the project's reputation.
Negative events or stagnation cause the project's reputation to decline over time.
As documented knowledge is internalized by contributors, it is converted from explicit to implicit, reducing the explicit stock.
The process of codifying tacit knowledge increases the stock of documented explicit knowledge.
New users adopting the software increase the total user base.
Users leaving the project decrease the total user base.
Merging or committing a pull request removes it from the 'under review' queue.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the 'under review' queue.
Initiating the review process for a new pull request adds it to the 'under review' stock.
Merging a pull request integrates new code, increasing the source code stock.
Accessible documentation helps contributors learn and improve their skills more quickly.
Direct mentorship accelerates learning and skill development for contributors.
Active community engagement in forums and chats produces content that enriches the knowledge base.
Open issues represent work to be done, often inspiring contributors to submit pull requests to address them.
Newly submitted pull requests flow into and increase the stock of new pull requests.
When a pull request enters review, it moves out of the 'new' stock and into the 'under review' stock.
Developers leaving the project reduce the number of core developers.
Promoting experienced contributors into core roles increases the core developer stock.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies experienced contributors for promotion to core roles.
When developers leave, their unique, undocumented knowledge is lost from the project.
Promoting an experienced contributor to a core role removes them from the experienced contributor stock.
As new contributors develop skills, they transition into the experienced contributor stock.
New contributors joining the project increase the stock of new contributors.
As new contributors skill up, they graduate out of the 'new contributor' stock.
The departure of experienced developers erodes the project's collective tacit knowledge.
As contributors internalize documented knowledge, it becomes part of the project's implicit knowledge base.
Formalizing tacit knowledge into documentation reduces its implicit, unspoken form.
Negative interactions and burnout degrade the collaborative spirit and well-being of the community.
Positive collaboration and reliable interactions build trust and strengthen community health.
